title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: In this view are comprehended the junction of the Tweed and Teviot, and the ruins of Roxburgh Castle ; in front, the palace of Fleurs, with its lawns sloping to the river's edge, and sheltered by lofty trees behind.

title: Over-Sea; or, England, France and Scotland as seen by a live American ... With numerous illustrations, etc
author: Morford, Henry.
snippet: And the Cirque de l'Imperatrice, or Circus of the Empress,standing at the North-west corner of the Champs, above theCarr6 or Square of Martigny and near the circle of the RondPoint—the Chateau des Fleurs and the Jardin Mabille—afford the beginning of a series of almost unceasing amusements, carried on by the cafes chantantt to which allusionhas before been made, and where the weakness of the roseflavored sugar-water which forms the favorite drink, is atonedfor by the strength and spiciness of many of the songs trilled out by bold and not-too-good-looking girls and rapturouslyapplauded by the loungers at the al fresco tables ; carriedon, I say, by those cafes, and supplemented by every description of itinerant musical arrangement and abomination, andevery conceivable form of cheap out-of-door diversion, knownto the history of public haunts.
